title: 110_hr5515
content: Section 233(e) of the Act is amended to allow agreements to enter into force after 60 days of transmittal to Congress. Documents must be delivered to both Houses of Congress on the same day. Any agreement entered into under this section must be transmitted to both Houses of Congress on the same day. The document must include a determination by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration regarding the impact of the agreement on the actuarial balance of the social security system over a 75-year period. The actuarial balance is defined as the difference between the adjusted summarized income rate and the adjusted summarized cost rate for the period. The term 'actuarial balance' refers to the difference between the adjusted summarized income rate and the adjusted summarized cost rate for a specific period. 'Taxable payroll' is defined as the total wages and self-employment income to be received during that period. The 'adjusted summarized income rate' is the ratio of the trust fund balance and total income from taxes to the taxable payroll, while the 'adjusted summarized cost rate' is the ratio of the cost during the period to the taxable payroll. The term 'trust fund balance' refers to the combined balance of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. 'Income from taxes' is the amounts deposited in the Trust Funds based on taxes under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. 'Cost' refers to disbursements from the Trust Funds during a period. The term 'income from taxes' refers to amounts deposited in the Trust Funds based on specific tax sections. 'Cost' includes disbursements from the Trust Funds during a period, excluding certain payments. 'Target trust fund balance' is defined as the desired balance level. The term 'target trust fund balance' refers to the necessary balance to support a 100 percent trust fund ratio for OASDI. The Chief Actuary uses the intermediate assumptions of the Board of Trustees for determinations. Agreements under this section will not take effect if a disapproving bill is enacted within 60 days. An agreement under this section will not take effect if a disapproving bill is enacted within 60 days. If the Chief Actuary determines a net reduction in the actuarial balance of the social security system by at least 0.005 percent of the present value of taxable payroll for a 75-year period due to the agreement, it will only enter into force if approved by a bill or joint resolution within the specified 60-day period. The agreement will not take effect unless a bill or joint resolution approving it is enacted within 60 days. The provisions in this paragraph are enacted by Congress as part of the rules for disapproval and approval resolutions, superseding other rules if inconsistent. During a 60-day period, Congress can consider a bill for approval or disapproval of an agreement with highest privilege. The agreement cannot be amended after being transmitted to Congress. The amendment applies to totalization arrangements under section 233 of the Social Security Act. The agreement cannot be amended after being transmitted to Congress. The amendment applies to totalization arrangements under section 233 of the Social Security Act, with a special rule for agreements signed by the Commissioner of Social Security in June 2004 and transmitted to Congress after September 1, 2007. The agreement signed by the Commissioner of Social Security in June 2004 and transmitted to Congress after September 1, 2007, shall not enter into force until certain conditions are met as outlined in section 233(e) of the Social Security Act. Additionally, biennial reports to Congress regarding the ongoing operation of totalization agreements are required. Section 233(e)(1) of the Social Security Act requires a report supporting the agreement, and biennial reports to Congress on the ongoing operation of totalization agreements are mandated. "Biennial Oversight Reports are required by Section 233(e)(1) of the Social Security Act for totalization agreements." The Commissioner of Social Security must submit biennial reports to Congress evaluating totalization agreements, including changes in benefit costs and contributions, fraudulent receipt of benefits, and integrity issues with other countries' data. The Commissioner of Social Security must submit biennial reports to Congress evaluating totalization agreements, including fraudulent receipt of benefits, integrity issues with other countries' data, and demographic trends affecting costs. The initial report must be submitted by December 31, 2008. SEC. 203 of the Social Security Act amends the suspension of benefits for individuals removed from the United States. No lump sum death payment shall be made to individuals removed after notification from the Attorney General or Secretary of Homeland Security. Effective after the twelfth month from the enactment of this Act.
